welcome.heading: Welcome to our Site!
welcome.paragraph: This is the website for the Norwich Sustainability Group. We focus on sustainable practices in the Norwich community through research, public engagement, and practical initiatives. We connect academic expertise from UEA with community action to address environmental challenges and promote sustainable living.

ueaResearch.heading: UEA's World-Leading Climate Change Research
ueaResearch.paragraph1: The University of East Anglia is a global climate science leader through its Climatic Research Unit and Tyndall Centre. Their research has shaped our understanding of climate change for decades. As a UEA student organization, we use this expertise in our community sustainability work.
ueaResearch.paragraph2: Our educational programs use UEA's research to highlight UN Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action. We create materials based on UEA's climate data and make science accessible to Norwich audiences. These initiatives help residents understand how global research connects to local challenges like coastal erosion.

image.alt: UEA campus with environmental science building and research facilities

norwichNetZero.heading: Norwich Pledges Net Zero by 2030
norwichNetZero.paragraph1: Norwich City Council has committed to carbon neutrality by 2030. The strategy includes energy transitions, transport changes, waste reduction, and green space preservation. This creates opportunities for a sustainable urban model that could inspire other UK cities.
norwichNetZero.paragraph2: We support this initiative through education about UN Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action. Our workshops show how household decisions contribute to city goals, with practical carbon reduction steps for different situations.

image.alt: Norwich cityscape showing sustainable urban development and green infrastructure

riversOfHope.heading: The Norfolk 'Rivers of Hope' Programme
riversOfHope.paragraph1: Norfolk's waterways face threats including agricultural runoff, sewage overflows, and plastic pollution. The 'Rivers of Hope' program coordinates scientists, authorities, and volunteers for comprehensive restoration.
riversOfHope.paragraph2: This initiative advances UN Sustainable Development Goal 6: Clean Water and Sanitation by engaging communities in water protection. We teach watershed management and pollution prevention strategies.

image.alt: Clean river in Norfolk with volunteers conducting scientific water testing and monitoring

co2Rates.heading: Global CO2 Rates Continue to Accelerate
co2Rates.paragraph1: Atmospheric CO2 has surpassed 421 parts per million - levels unprecedented in human history. Current emission paths exceed Paris Agreement targets. In East Anglia, we see climate impacts through changing weather patterns and sea level rise.
co2Rates.paragraph2: We use this data to emphasize UN Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action urgency. Through carbon footprint workshops and policy advocacy, we bridge climate science with local responsibility.

image.alt: Scientific climate data visualization showing dramatically rising global CO2 levels and temperature trends

transport.heading: Transport: UK's Largest Greenhouse Gas Emitting Sector
transport.paragraph1: Transport produces 27% of UK emissions, mostly from road vehicles creating urban air quality issues. Norwich's growth increases traffic and pollution, requiring integrated solutions.
transport.paragraph2: Our transport work supports UN Sustainable Development Goal 13: Climate Action through EV adoption workshops, cycling courses, and infrastructure advocacy. We promote better cycling networks and expanded EV charging to shift Norwich toward more sustainable travel.

image.alt: Cyclists, pedestrians, and electric buses sharing sustainable transportation infrastructure in Norwich city center

rivers.heading: UK's Rivers and Coasts: The Sewage Crisis
rivers.paragraph1: UK water companies discharge sewage hundreds of thousands of times yearly, with Norfolk's waterways particularly affected. This represents infrastructure and regulatory failures with environmental and health consequences.
rivers.paragraph2: We address this crisis through UN Sustainable Development Goal 6: Clean Water and Sanitation via water monitoring training, cleanup events, and conservation education.

image.alt: Diverse community volunteers actively cleaning riverbank pollution and restoring habitat in Norfolk waterway

norwichStandUp.heading: Norwich Can Stand Up for Sustainability
norwichStandUp.paragraph1: Norwich has advantages that position our city to become a national leader in urban sustainability. These include world-class research institutions like UEA, an engaged citizenry, and progressive local government.
norwichStandUp.paragraph2: Our student-led organization focuses on UN Sustainable Development Goals 4 (Quality Education), 6 (Clean Water), and 13 (Climate Action). We teach systems thinking and collaborative problem-solving needed to address sustainability challenges.

image.alt: Vibrant community garden in Norwich with diverse volunteers of all ages engaged in sustainable urban agriculture

signUpNow.heading: Join Norwich Sustainability Group Today
signUpNow.paragraph1: Join Norwich Sustainability Group to connect with others who care about creating a more sustainable future. By signing up, you'll become part of our community working together on local environmental projects.
signUpNow.paragraph2: Signing up gives you access to our events, workshops, and volunteer opportunities. You'll receive updates about our activities and learn practical ways to make a difference in Norwich's sustainability journey.

image.alt: Diverse group of Norwich residents engaging in community sustainability event with educational displays and activities

section1.heading: Challenges the Climate is Facing
section1.paragraph1: Climate change is currently one of the world's biggest challenges. Climate change is responsible for changes in heather, and more examples of extreme whether events around the world. This includes wildfires, glaciers melting, and more extreme temperatures being recorded all over the world.

image.alt: A photo showing a dense rainforest in Ghana. Trees fill the bottom of the picture, and the top fades into a white sky.

section1.paragraph2: Generative AI is known for using a vast amount of energy to run its data centres, which is often gained from unsustainable sources. It also produces a huge amount of CO2 every year, which is a major contributor to the greenhouse effect and climate change. Using more renewable energy would decrease the amount of CO2 emitted, and reduce climate change, however most of the world is still reliant on fossil fuels, due to them being cheap and easy to access in large quantities, despite the large cost for the planet.

image.alt: A photo showing a dense rainforest in Ghana. Trees fill the bottom of the picture, and the top fades into a white sky.

section2.heading: How This Impacts Norwich
section2.paragraph1: There are many ways that individuals and organisations living in Norwich can help to reduce the growth of climate change. One way is to cut use of generative AI tools from personal and work use. If generative AI stopped being used, and the data centres shut down, it would greatly decrease the amount of CO2 emitted each year.
section2.paragraph2: Additionally, reducing waste, and use of single-use plastic can help to prevent climate change. This is beneficial, as recycling plastic releases microplastics into the water supply, which could have a negative impact on peoples' health.

section1.heading: Challenges Regarding Clean Water and Sanitation
section1.paragraph1: Water is the most important resource needed for people to live, and access to water is a human right. Despite this, many people around the world don't have access to clean water.Without access to clean water, people cannot have access to proper sanitation, which greatly increases the spread of diseases, and decreases quality of life drastically.

image.alt: A photo showing a beach in England, which is covered in various pieces of rubbish, such as plastic bags.

section1.paragraph2: Generative AI is known for using a huge amount of fresh water in order to cool its data centres. This has already been seen to have a huge effect on communities, by causing water shortages, and its predicted to cause even more on a much larger scale in the very near future. Additionally, climate change is the cause of many droughts worldwide, which have large negative impacts on people, and local wildlife

image.alt: A photo showing a beach in England, which is covered in various pieces of rubbish, such as plastic bags.

section2.heading: How This Impacts Norwich
section2.paragraph1: There are many ways that individuals and organisations living in Norwich can help to improve the lack of fresh water available worldwide.
section2.paragraph2: One way is to cut use of generative AI tools from personal and work use. If generative AI stopped being used, and the data centres shut down, a vast amount of water would stop being wasted. Additionally, people can reduce the waste of water in other ways, such as taking shorter showers of possible, and not washing clothes more frequently than necessary.

section1.heading: Challenges Within Education
section1.paragraph1: Education is one of the most important factors affecting peoples' opportunities in life, and many children are still not in education. There remains a gender divide within education, as many women and girls cannot access education at all, or may have more limited options in terms of the subjects they are allowed to study.

image.alt: A photo showing UEA's campus accomodation, which is a collection of white concrete buildings, shaped like pyrimids with steps carved into them.

section1.paragraph2: Additionally, there is a large digital divide within different parts of the world, which can prevent the same quality of education being available to everyone. Digital divide refers to the fact that not everyone has the same access to technology and the internet. This can prevent students from being able to learn as effectively, and deny them opportunities. A lack of funding can also have an impact on the resources that schools are able to use, and create or prevent opportunities for students. It is important that students from all financial backgrounds are able to have equal access to education.

image.alt: A photo showing UEA's campus accomodation, which is a collection of white concrete buildings, shaped like pyrimids with steps carved into them.

section2.heading: How This Impacts Norwich
section2.paragraph1: In order to improve equality within education for Norwich, a focus needs to be given to creating financial equality, so that students are not disadvantaged based on their household income.
section2.paragraph2: Additionally, statistics show that the number of women taking Computer Science degrees is roughly 21%. In order to increase the number of female students taking this degree, attention needs to be given to ensuring girls are offered and taking part in STEM based activities in primary and secondary school in order to help make this statistic more equal.
